text.0: thou at thy birth art varuṇa o agni when thou art kindled thou becomest mitra.
text.1: in thee o son of strength all gods are centred indra art thou to man who brings oblation.
text.2: aryaman art thou as regardeth maidens mysterious is thy name o selfsustainer.
text.3: as a kind friend with streams of milk they balm thee what time thou makest wife and lord oneminded.
text.4: the maruts deck their beauty for thy glory yea rudra for thy birth fair brightlycoloured.
text.5: that which was fixed as viṣṇus loftiest stationtherewith the secret of the cows thou guardest.
text.6: gods through thy glory god who art so lovely granting abundant gifts gained life immortal.
text.7: as their own priest have men established agni and serve him fain for praise from him who liveth.
text.8: there is no priest more skilled than thou in worship none selfsustainer pass thee in wisdom.
text.9: the man within whose house as guest thou dwellest o god by sacrifice shall conquer mortals.
text.10: aided by thee o agni may we conquer through our oblation fain for wealth awakened.
text.11: may we in battle in the days assemblies o son of strength by riches conquer mortals.
text.12: he shall bring evil on the evilplotter whoever turns against us sin and outrage.
text.13: destroy this calumny of him o agni whoever injures us with doubledealing.
text.14: at this dawns flushing god our ancient fathers served thee with offerings making thee their envoy.
text.15: when agni to the store of wealth thou goest a god enkindled with good things by mortals.
text.16: save thou who knowest draw thy father near thee who counts as thine own son o child of power.
text.17: o sapient agni when wilt thou regard us when skilled in holy law wilt thou direct us.
text.18: adoring thee he gives thee many a title when thou good lord acceptest this as father.
text.19: and doth not agni glad in strength of godhead gain splendid bliss when he hath waxen mighty.
text.20: most youthful agni verily thou bearest thy praiser safely over all his troubles.
text.21: thieves have been seen by us and open foemen unknown have been the plottings of the wicked.
text.22: to thee these eulogies have been directed or to the vasu hath this sin been spoken.
text.23: but this our agni flaming high shall never yield us to calumny to him who wrongs us.
